english_definition: Breakfast (more formal/neutral than あさごはん). Often used in daily routine or travel contexts.
japanese_example: <ruby>朝食<rt>ちょうしょく</rt></ruby>は<ruby>七時<rt>しちじ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>食<rt>た</rt></ruby>べます。
english_example: I eat breakfast at seven o’clock.

english_definition: An animal’s cry/call (sound it makes). Used for birds, insects, pets, etc.
japanese_example: <ruby>森<rt>もり</rt></ruby>で<ruby>鳥<rt>とり</rt></ruby>の<ruby>鳴<rt>な</rt></ruby>き<ruby>声<rt>ごえ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>聞<rt>き</rt></ruby>こえた。
english_example: In the forest, I heard a bird’s call.

english_definition: A shout/yell (noun), often harsh or angry. Common as 怒鳴り声 (a yelling voice).
japanese_example: <ruby>廊下<rt>ろうか</rt></ruby>に<ruby>怒鳴<rt>どな</rt></ruby>りが<ruby>響<rt>ひび</rt></ruby>いた。
english_example: Shouting echoed down the hallway.

english_definition: Owl.
japanese_example: <ruby>夜<rt>よる</rt></ruby>にふくろうが<ruby>鳴<rt>な</rt></ruby>いていた。
english_example: An owl was hooting at night.

english_definition: To fall silent; to shut up (intransitive). Often implies stopping speech intentionally or suddenly.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>質問<rt>しつもん</rt></ruby>されると<ruby>急<rt>きゅう</rt></ruby>に<ruby>黙<rt>だま</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: When he was questioned, he suddenly fell silent.

english_definition: To make someone be quiet; to silence (causative of 黙る). Takes an object marked with を.
japanese_example: <ruby>先生<rt>せんせい</rt></ruby>はうるさい<ruby>生徒<rt>せいと</rt></ruby>を<ruby>黙<rt>だま</rt></ruby>らせた。
english_example: The teacher silenced the noisy student.

english_definition: Cannot make someone be quiet; unable to silence (negative of potential/ability form of 黙らせる).
japanese_example: <ruby>何<rt>なに</rt></ruby>を<ruby>言<rt>い</rt></ruby>っても、<ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>黙<rt>だま</rt></ruby>らせられない。
english_example: No matter what I say, I can’t make him be quiet.

english_definition: If; in the case of ~ (sets a condition based on a topic/assumption, often “as for ~” or “if it’s ~”). Common for advice or reactions.
japanese_example: <ruby>時間<rt>じかん</rt></ruby>がないなら、<ruby>先<rt>さき</rt></ruby>に<ruby>電話<rt>でんわ</rt></ruby>しておいて。
english_example: If you don’t have time, call ahead first.

english_definition: To dispose of; get rid of; deal with (something troublesome). Can sound firm or cold depending on context.
japanese_example: <ruby>古<rt>ふる</rt></ruby>い<ruby>家具<rt>かぐ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>今週<rt>こんしゅう</rt></ruby><ruby>中<rt>ちゅう</rt></ruby>に<ruby>始末<rt>しまつ</rt></ruby>する<ruby>予定<rt>よてい</rt></ruby>だ。
english_example: I plan to get rid of the old furniture this week.

english_definition: Rough imperative: “Get rid of it already.” Uses 〜てしまえ (blunt command) to push for completion.
japanese_example: そんなものはさっさと<ruby>始末<rt>しまつ</rt></ruby>してしまえ。
english_example: Just get rid of that already.

english_definition: Do (something) completely/finish it; also often implies regret or that it happened unintentionally. Casual contraction: 〜ちゃう.
japanese_example: <ruby>大事<rt>だいじ</rt></ruby>な<ruby>書類<rt>しょるい</rt></ruby>を<ruby>捨<rt>す</rt></ruby>ててしまった。
english_example: I ended up throwing away an important document.

english_definition: To be fed up; sick of something (stronger than 飽きる in many contexts). Often used with に: 〜にうんざりする.
japanese_example: <ruby>同<rt>おな</rt></ruby>じ<ruby>話<rt>はなし</rt></ruby>ばかりで<ruby>本当<rt>ほんとう</rt></ruby>にうんざりする。
english_example: I’m really fed up because it’s always the same story.

english_definition: To go around; to rotate/turn; to make the rounds. Meaning depends on context (physical rotation vs. visiting).
japanese_example: <ruby>地球<rt>ちきゅう</rt></ruby>は<ruby>太陽<rt>たいよう</rt></ruby>の<ruby>周<rt>まわ</rt></ruby>りを<ruby>回<rt>まわ</rt></ruby>っている。
english_example: The Earth revolves around the Sun.

english_definition: To fly around; flit about; dash around (busy movement in many directions). Used for birds, kids, busy people, etc.
japanese_example: <ruby>子<rt>こ</rt></ruby>どもたちが<ruby>公園<rt>こうえん</rt></ruby>を<ruby>飛<rt>と</rt></ruby>び<ruby>回<rt>まわ</rt></ruby>っている。
english_example: The children are running around the park.

english_definition: Excuse; justification (often implying “making excuses”). Common pattern: 言い訳をする.
japanese_example: <ruby>遅<rt>おく</rt></ruby>れた<ruby>理由<rt>りゆう</rt></ruby>を<ruby>言<rt>い</rt></ruby>い<ruby>訳<rt>わけ</rt></ruby>にするな。
english_example: Don’t use your reason for being late as an excuse.

english_definition: To repeat; to do again and again. Used for actions, mistakes, statements, patterns.
japanese_example: <ruby>同<rt>おな</rt></ruby>じ<ruby>失敗<rt>しっぱい</rt></ruby>を<ruby>繰<rt>く</rt></ruby>り<ruby>返<rt>かえ</rt></ruby>さないようにしよう。
english_example: Let’s try not to repeat the same mistake.

english_definition: To release; let go (physically). Contrast with 話す (to speak) and 離す (to separate).
japanese_example: <ruby>危<rt>あぶ</rt></ruby>ないから、<ruby>手<rt>て</rt></ruby>を<ruby>放<rt>はな</rt></ruby>さないで。
english_example: It’s dangerous, so don’t let go of my hand.

english_definition: To retort; to talk back in response. Often implies defiance or pushing back verbally.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>上司<rt>じょうし</rt></ruby>に<ruby>言<rt>い</rt></ruby>い<ruby>返<rt>かえ</rt></ruby>してしまった。
english_example: He ended up talking back to his boss.

english_definition: To try/attempt to do; to be about to do (volitional + とする). Used for intention or immediate attempt.
japanese_example: <ruby>出<rt>で</rt></ruby>かけようとしたとき、<ruby>雨<rt>あめ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>降<rt>ふ</rt></ruby>り<ruby>出<rt>だ</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: When I was about to go out, it started to rain.

english_definition: Tried to; attempted to (past of 〜とする), often implying the attempt was interrupted or did not go as planned.
japanese_example: <ruby>立<rt>た</rt></ruby>とうとしたが、<ruby>足<rt>あし</rt></ruby>が<ruby>痛<rt>いた</rt></ruby>くて<ruby>動<rt>うご</rt></ruby>けなかった。
english_example: I tried to stand up, but my leg hurt and I couldn’t move.

english_definition: To look at each other; to exchange looks (often in reaction). Also can mean “to postpone,” but this card is the “look at each other” sense.
japanese_example: <ruby>二人<rt>ふたり</rt></ruby>は<ruby>思<rt>おも</rt></ruby>わず<ruby>見<rt>み</rt></ruby>合わせた。
english_example: The two of them instinctively looked at each other.

english_definition: To exchange glances; to look at each other’s faces (often showing confusion, surprise, etc.).
japanese_example: <ruby>突然<rt>とつぜん</rt></ruby>の<ruby>知<rt>し</rt></ruby>らせに、<ruby>皆<rt>みな</rt></ruby>が<ruby>顔<rt>かお</rt></ruby>を<ruby>見<rt>み</rt></ruby><ruby>合<rt>あ</rt></ruby>わせた。
english_example: At the sudden news, everyone exchanged glances.

english_definition: To swallow; also “to grasp/understand” metaphorically. Literal sense often with 食べ物/薬/つば, etc.
japanese_example: <ruby>薬<rt>くすり</rt></ruby>を<ruby>水<rt>みず</rt></ruby>で<ruby>飲<rt>の</rt></ruby>み<ruby>込<rt>こ</rt></ruby>んだ。
english_example: I swallowed the medicine with water.

english_definition: Swallowed (completely / ended up swallowing), with 〜てしまう adding completion or “unfortunately/accidentally.”
japanese_example: <ruby>慌<rt>あわ</rt></ruby>てて<ruby>話<rt>はな</rt></ruby>して、<ruby>唾<rt>つば</rt></ruby>を<ruby>飲<rt>の</rt></ruby>み<ruby>込<rt>こ</rt></ruby>んでしまった。
english_example: I spoke in a rush and ended up swallowing my saliva.

english_definition: Entranced; spellbound (adverb/na-adj-like). Used for being captivated by beauty, music, a view, etc.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼女<rt>かのじょ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>夜景<rt>やけい</rt></ruby>にうっとりしていた。
english_example: She was entranced by the night view.

english_definition: To gaze at; to look out at (for a while, calmly). Implies viewing something as a scene.
japanese_example: <ruby>窓<rt>まど</rt></ruby>から<ruby>海<rt>うみ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>眺<rt>なが</rt></ruby>めるのが<ruby>好<rt>す</rt></ruby>きだ。
english_example: I like gazing at the ocean from the window.

english_definition: At least (minimum concession/wish). Often used when hoping for a smaller, acceptable outcome.
japanese_example: せめて<ruby>今日<rt>きょう</rt></ruby>だけは<ruby>早<rt>はや</rt></ruby>く<ruby>帰<rt>かえ</rt></ruby>りたい。
english_example: At least today, I want to go home early.

english_definition: Casual “have to; must,” contraction of 〜なくては. Common in speech; more casual than 〜なければならない.
japanese_example: <ruby>明日<rt>あした</rt></ruby>は<ruby>早<rt>はや</rt></ruby>いから、もう<ruby>寝<rt>ね</rt></ruby>なくちゃ。
english_example: I have an early day tomorrow, so I’ve got to sleep now.

english_definition: Somehow; kind of; for some reason (vague feeling). Often used when you can’t explain why.
japanese_example: なんだか<ruby>胸<rt>むね</rt></ruby>がざわざわする。
english_example: Somehow, I feel uneasy.

english_definition: Around (a time); about when. Used after time expressions: 子どもの頃, 三時頃, etc.
japanese_example: <ruby>三時<rt>さんじ</rt></ruby><ruby>頃<rt>ころ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>迎<rt>むか</rt></ruby>えに<ruby>来<rt>き</rt></ruby>てください。
english_example: Please come pick me up around three o’clock.

english_definition: Around the time someone was (at a place / in a state); when someone used to be. Built with いる in past: 〜いていたころ → often shortened to 〜いたころ.
japanese_example: <ruby>日本<rt>にほん</rt></ruby>にいたころ、よく<ruby>銭湯<rt>せんとう</rt></ruby>に<ruby>行<rt>い</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: When I was in Japan, I often went to public baths.

english_definition: Casual “the fact that (it) isn’t ~,” often used for emphasis, surprise, or confirming a point. Based on 〜ないということ.
japanese_example: <ruby>今日<rt>きょう</rt></ruby>は<ruby>休<rt>やす</rt></ruby>みじゃないってこと？
english_example: So you’re saying it’s not a day off today?

english_definition: Ridiculous; outrageous; impossible. Also used as “Not at all / Don’t mention it” in polite responses.
japanese_example: そんなの、とんでもない<ruby>話<rt>はなし</rt></ruby>だ。
english_example: That’s a ridiculous story.

english_definition: Adverb form: ridiculously; outrageously; unbelievably (modifies verbs/adjectives).
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>はとんでもなく<ruby>足<rt>あし</rt></ruby>が<ruby>速<rt>はや</rt></ruby>い。
english_example: He is unbelievably fast.

english_definition: Just because; simply due to ~, leading to an undesirable result or regret. Attaches to plain form (often past): 〜たばかりに.
japanese_example: <ruby>一度<rt>いちど</rt></ruby><ruby>手伝<rt>てつだ</rt></ruby>ったばかりに、ずっと<ruby>頼<rt>たの</rt></ruby>まれるようになった。
english_example: Just because I helped once, I started being asked all the time.

english_definition: “Something like ~” (often with contempt, disbelief, or emphasis). Can also quote content casually: 〜なんて言う.
japanese_example: <ruby>失敗<rt>しっぱい</rt></ruby>なんて<ruby>気<rt>き</rt></ruby>にするな。
english_example: Don’t worry about something like a mistake.

english_definition: Hunger; empty stomach (noun). Often used in phrases like 空腹を感じる or 空腹で.
japanese_example: <ruby>空腹<rt>くうふく</rt></ruby>で<ruby>力<rt>ちから</rt></ruby>が<ruby>出<rt>で</rt></ruby>ない。
english_example: I’m so hungry I have no energy.

english_definition: Satisfaction; being satisfied (noun/する-verb). Common: 満足する, 満足だ.
japanese_example: <ruby>結果<rt>けっか</rt></ruby>には<ruby>満足<rt>まんぞく</rt></ruby>している。
english_example: I’m satisfied with the result.

english_definition: Satisfactorily; properly/adequately (often in negatives: 満足に〜ない = not adequately).
japanese_example: <ruby>最近<rt>さいきん</rt></ruby>は<ruby>満足<rt>まんぞく</rt></ruby>に<ruby>寝<rt>ね</rt></ruby>られていない。
english_example: Lately I haven’t been able to sleep properly.

english_definition: Looking satisfied; seemingly satisfied (〜げ = “with an air of”). Describes appearance/attitude.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>満足<rt>まんぞく</rt></ruby>げな<ruby>顔<rt>かお</rt></ruby>でうなずいた。
english_example: He nodded with a satisfied look.

english_definition: Should; expected to; it’s supposed to be (based on reasoning or prior knowledge).
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>はもう<ruby>家<rt>いえ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>着<rt>つ</rt></ruby>いたはずだ。
english_example: He should have arrived home by now.

english_definition: Speaking of ~; when it comes to ~ (topic emphasis). Often used to highlight how extreme/notable something is.
japanese_example: <ruby>夏<rt>なつ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>暑<rt>あつ</rt></ruby>さと<ruby>言<rt>い</rt></ruby>ったら、<ruby>耐<rt>た</rt></ruby>えられない。
english_example: Speaking of summer heat, it’s unbearable.

english_definition: To stick out; to protrude; to overflow (go beyond a boundary).
japanese_example: <ruby>紙<rt>かみ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>封筒<rt>ふうとう</rt></ruby>からはみ<ruby>出<rt>だ</rt></ruby>している。
english_example: The paper is sticking out of the envelope.

japanese: 箱からはみ出している
hiragana: はこからはみだしている
english_definition: Sticking out of the box (state). Uses はみ出す in progressive/state form: 〜ている.
japanese_example: <ruby>帽子<rt>ぼうし</rt></ruby>が<ruby>箱<rt>はこ</rt></ruby>からはみ<ruby>出<rt>だ</rt></ruby>している。
english_example: A hat is sticking out of the box.

english_definition: To hang down; to droop (intransitive). Used for hair, cloth, cords, branches, etc.
japanese_example: <ruby>電線<rt>でんせん</rt></ruby>が<ruby>低<rt>ひく</rt></ruby>く<ruby>垂<rt>た</rt></ruby>れ<ruby>下<rt>さ</rt></ruby>がっている。
english_example: A power line is hanging low.

english_definition: With a sly grin; smirking (sound-symbolic adverb). Often paired with 笑う.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>はニタっと<ruby>笑<rt>わら</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: He smirked.

english_definition: To add (something additional, as an extra note) to what was already said/written. Common in speech: 付け加えると.
japanese_example: <ruby>最後<rt>さいご</rt></ruby>に<ruby>一言<rt>ひとこと</rt></ruby>だけ<ruby>付<rt>つ</rt></ruby>け<ruby>加<rt>くわ</rt></ruby>えると、<ruby>安全<rt>あんぜん</rt></ruby>が<ruby>最優先<rt>さいゆうせん</rt></ruby>です。
english_example: To add one last thing, safety is the top priority.

english_definition: To add; to include; to apply (pressure, heat, etc.). More general than 付け加える.
japanese_example: <ruby>塩<rt>しお</rt></ruby>を<ruby>少<rt>すこ</rt></ruby>し<ruby>加<rt>くわ</rt></ruby>えて<ruby>味<rt>あじ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>調整<rt>ちょうせい</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: I added a little salt to adjust the flavor.

english_definition: Quite ordinary; completely normal. ごく intensifies “ordinary.”
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>はごく<ruby>普通<rt>ふつう</rt></ruby>の<ruby>会社員<rt>かいしゃいん</rt></ruby>だ。
english_example: He’s a completely ordinary office worker.

english_definition: An entirely ordinary thing; something perfectly normal.
japanese_example: <ruby>挨拶<rt>あいさつ</rt></ruby>するのはごく<ruby>普通<rt>ふつう</rt></ruby>のことだ。
english_example: Greeting people is a perfectly normal thing.

english_definition: Can eat (potential) / be eaten (passive); meaning depends on context and subject/object marking.
japanese_example: <ruby>今夜<rt>こんや</rt></ruby>は<ruby>辛<rt>から</rt></ruby>いものも<ruby>食<rt>た</rt></ruby>べられる。
english_example: Tonight I can even eat spicy food.

hiragana: わたしはにくをたべられた
english_definition: Potential past: “I was able to eat meat.” Context should make it clear it’s ability, not passive.
japanese_example: <ruby>体調<rt>たいちょう</rt></ruby>が<ruby>戻<rt>もど</rt></ruby>って、<ruby>私<rt>わたし</rt></ruby>は<ruby>肉<rt>にく</rt></ruby>を<ruby>食<rt>た</rt></ruby>べられた。
english_example: After I recovered, I was able to eat meat.

english_definition: Passive past: “The meat was eaten.” Topic は often marks the item affected.
japanese_example: <ruby>冷蔵庫<rt>れいぞうこ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>肉<rt>にく</rt></ruby>は<ruby>全部<rt>ぜんぶ</rt></ruby><ruby>食<rt>た</rt></ruby>べられた。
english_example: All the meat in the fridge was eaten.

english_definition: Effect; efficacy (especially of medicine, remedies, measures). Common: 効き目がある/ない.
japanese_example: この<ruby>薬<rt>くすり</rt></ruby>は<ruby>効<rt>き</rt></ruby>き<ruby>目<rt>め</rt></ruby>が<ruby>早<rt>はや</rt></ruby>い。
english_example: This medicine works quickly.

english_definition: To express; to represent; to show (feelings, meaning, symbols). Often used in writing or formal contexts.
japanese_example: <ruby>数字<rt>すうじ</rt></ruby>で<ruby>成長<rt>せいちょう</rt></ruby>を<ruby>表<rt>あらわ</rt></ruby>す。
english_example: Represent growth with numbers.

english_definition: Breath. Common: 息をする, 息が切れる, 息をのむ.
japanese_example: <ruby>深<rt>ふか</rt></ruby>く<ruby>息<rt>いき</rt></ruby>をして<ruby>落<rt>お</rt></ruby>ち<ruby>着<rt>つ</rt></ruby>いて。
english_example: Take a deep breath and calm down.

english_definition: Causative: make/let someone do (verb causative form). Often marks the person made/allowed with に or を depending on verb type/nuance.
japanese_example: <ruby>母<rt>はは</rt></ruby>は<ruby>私<rt>わたし</rt></ruby>に<ruby>野菜<rt>やさい</rt></ruby>を<ruby>食<rt>た</rt></ruby>べさせた。
english_example: My mother made/let me eat vegetables.

english_definition: Causative-passive: be made to do (forced to do). Emphasizes unwillingness or being compelled.
japanese_example: <ruby>私<rt>わたし</rt></ruby>は<ruby>上司<rt>じょうし</rt></ruby>に<ruby>残業<rt>ざんぎょう</rt></ruby>させられた。
english_example: I was made to work overtime by my boss.

japanese: 母は私にケーキを食べさせた
hiragana: はははわたしにけーきをたべさせた
english_definition: Example of causative: “Mom made/let me eat cake.” Shows 食べる → 食べさせる.
japanese_example: <ruby>母<rt>はは</rt></ruby>は<ruby>私<rt>わたし</rt></ruby>にケーキを<ruby>食<rt>た</rt></ruby>べさせた。
english_example: My mom made/let me eat cake.

japanese: 先生は学生に漢字を書かせた
hiragana: せんせいはがくせいにかんじをかかせた
english_definition: Example of causative: “The teacher made students write kanji.” Shows 書く → 書かせる.
japanese_example: <ruby>先生<rt>せんせい</rt></ruby>は<ruby>学生<rt>がくせい</rt></ruby>に<ruby>漢字<rt>かんじ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>書<rt>か</rt></ruby>かせた。
english_example: The teacher made the students write kanji.

japanese: 私は母にケーキを食べさせられた
hiragana: わたしはははにけーきをたべさせられた
english_definition: Example of causative-passive: “I was made to eat cake by my mom.” Shows 食べさせる → 食べさせられる.
japanese_example: <ruby>私<rt>わたし</rt></ruby>は<ruby>母<rt>はは</rt></ruby>にケーキを<ruby>食<rt>た</rt></ruby>べさせられた。
english_example: I was made to eat cake by my mother.

japanese: 学生は先生に漢字を書かされた
hiragana: がくせいはせんせいにかんじをかかされた
english_definition: Example of causative-passive (past): “Students were made to write kanji by the teacher.” Uses 書かされる (shorter causative-passive).
japanese_example: <ruby>学生<rt>がくせい</rt></ruby>は<ruby>先生<rt>せんせい</rt></ruby>に<ruby>漢字<rt>かんじ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>書<rt>か</rt></ruby>かされた。
english_example: The students were made to write kanji by the teacher.

english_definition: To be clogged; to get stuck; to choke (intransitive). Used for pipes, traffic, throat, etc.
japanese_example: <ruby>喉<rt>のど</rt></ruby>が<ruby>詰<rt>つ</rt></ruby>まって<ruby>声<rt>こえ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>出<rt>で</rt></ruby>ない。
english_example: My throat feels choked up and I can’t speak.

english_definition: “Breath is choked” (state), describing being unable to breathe freely from stress, emotion, tightness, etc.
japanese_example: <ruby>緊張<rt>きんちょう</rt></ruby>で<ruby>息<rt>いき</rt></ruby>が<ruby>詰<rt>つ</rt></ruby>まってしまった。
english_example: I got so nervous that my breathing felt choked.

english_definition: To choke up; to make one’s breath catch (often from crying, shock, or laughter). Uses transitive 詰まらせる.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼女<rt>かのじょ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>涙<rt>なみだ</rt></ruby>で<ruby>息<rt>いき</rt></ruby>を<ruby>詰<rt>つ</rt></ruby>まらせた。
english_example: She choked up with tears.

english_definition: To shake; to sway; to wobble (intransitive). Used for earthquakes, hanging objects, feelings wavering, etc.
japanese_example: <ruby>地震<rt>じしん</rt></ruby>で<ruby>家<rt>いえ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>大<rt>おお</rt></ruby>きく<ruby>揺<rt>ゆ</rt></ruby>れた。
english_example: The house shook strongly in the earthquake.

english_definition: Madam; Mrs. (formal). Used for someone’s wife in respectful/formal settings (e.g., 大統領夫人).
japanese_example: <ruby>夫人<rt>ふじん</rt></ruby>はにこやかに<ruby>挨拶<rt>あいさつ</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: The madam greeted us with a smile.

english_definition: A shriek; scream (noun). Common: 悲鳴を上げる, 悲鳴が聞こえる.
japanese_example: <ruby>突然<rt>とつぜん</rt></ruby><ruby>悲鳴<rt>ひめい</rt></ruby>が<ruby>聞<rt>き</rt></ruby>こえて、<ruby>皆<rt>みな</rt></ruby>が<ruby>振<rt>ふ</rt></ruby>り<ruby>向<rt>む</rt></ruby>いた。
english_example: A scream suddenly rang out, and everyone turned around.

english_definition: Both hands. Often used for actions done with two hands: 両手で持つ.
japanese_example: <ruby>両手<rt>りょうて</rt></ruby>でしっかり<ruby>包<rt>つつ</rt></ruby>んで<ruby>持<rt>も</rt></ruby>ってください。
english_example: Please hold it firmly with both hands.

english_definition: Temple (side of the head). Often appears with 押さえる, 叩く, etc.
japanese_example: <ruby>頭痛<rt>ずつう</rt></ruby>でこめかみを<ruby>押<rt>お</rt></ruby>さえた。
english_example: I pressed my temples because of a headache.

english_definition: Muscle/tendon; vein; line/plot thread; logic (“a point”). Meaning varies by context.
japanese_example: <ruby>話<rt>はなし</rt></ruby>の<ruby>筋<rt>すじ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>分<rt>わ</rt></ruby>からなくなった。
english_example: I lost track of the thread of the story.

english_definition: Twitching (sound-symbolic). Used for small repeated muscle movements or slight reactions.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>頬<rt>ほお</rt></ruby>がピクピク<ruby>動<rt>うご</rt></ruby>いた。
english_example: His cheek twitched.

english_definition: To panic; to be flustered; to hurry in confusion. Often paired with ないで: 慌てないで.
japanese_example: <ruby>慌<rt>あわ</rt></ruby>てずに、ゆっくり<ruby>説明<rt>せつめい</rt></ruby>してください。
english_example: Don’t rush—please explain slowly.

japanese: おまえに言ったはずだな？
hiragana: おまえにいったはずだな？
english_definition: Rough/masculine: “I told you, didn’t I?” Uses はず to insist it was said/should be known; おまえ is blunt “you.”
japanese_example: おまえに<ruby>言<rt>い</rt></ruby>ったはずだな？
english_example: I told you, didn’t I?

english_definition: What would happen if ~? Uses conditional 〜たら plus どうなる to ask about the consequence.
japanese_example: <ruby>今<rt>いま</rt></ruby><ruby>押<rt>お</rt></ruby>したらどうなるか<ruby>考<rt>かんが</rt></ruby>えてみて。
english_example: Think about what would happen if you pressed it now.

english_definition: Saliva; spit (noun). Common: 唾を飲み込む, 唾を吐く.
japanese_example: <ruby>緊張<rt>きんちょう</rt></ruby>して<ruby>唾<rt>つば</rt></ruby>を<ruby>飲<rt>の</rt></ruby>み<ruby>込<rt>こ</rt></ruby>んだ。
english_example: I got nervous and swallowed my saliva.

english_definition: To spit out; to vomit; to exhale (breath). Meaning depends on object (唾, 息, blood, etc.).
japanese_example: <ruby>冷<rt>つめ</rt></ruby>たい<ruby>空気<rt>くうき</rt></ruby>を<ruby>息<rt>いき</rt></ruby>として<ruby>吐<rt>は</rt></ruby>いた。
english_example: I exhaled the cold air as breath.

english_definition: To scatter; to strew; to spread around (transitive).
japanese_example: <ruby>子<rt>こ</rt></ruby>どもが<ruby>部屋<rt>へや</rt></ruby>におもちゃを<ruby>散<rt>ち</rt></ruby>らした。
english_example: The child scattered toys around the room.

english_definition: To spit out and scatter (forcefully). Built from 吐く + 散らす; often vivid/rough description.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>唾<rt>つば</rt></ruby>を<ruby>吐<rt>は</rt></ruby>き<ruby>散<rt>ち</rt></ruby>らしながら<ruby>怒鳴<rt>どな</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: He yelled while spitting saliva everywhere.

english_definition: While doing ~; at the same time. Attaches to verb stem: 食べながら, 聞きながら.
japanese_example: <ruby>音楽<rt>おんがく</rt></ruby>を<ruby>聞<rt>き</rt></ruby>きながら<ruby>勉強<rt>べんきょう</rt></ruby>する。
english_example: I study while listening to music.

english_definition: To threaten; to intimidate (transitive). Often used with a person as object: 人を脅す.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>金<rt>かね</rt></ruby>を<ruby>出<rt>だ</rt></ruby>せと<ruby>店員<rt>てんいん</rt></ruby>を<ruby>脅<rt>おど</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: He threatened the clerk, demanding money.

english_definition: “How dare you…!” Expression of outrage; often followed by negative judgment or accusation.
japanese_example: よくもそんなことが<ruby>言<rt>い</rt></ruby>えたな。
english_example: How dare you say something like that.

english_definition: “You’ve done it now” / “Nice one…” said with anger or sarcasm after someone causes trouble. Very colloquial.
japanese_example: やってくれたな、<ruby>後<rt>あと</rt></ruby>で<ruby>覚<rt>おぼ</rt></ruby>えていろ。
english_example: You’ve done it now—just you wait.

english_definition: Fist. Common: 拳を握る, 拳で叩く.
japanese_example: <ruby>拳<rt>こぶし</rt></ruby>を<ruby>握<rt>にぎ</rt></ruby>って<ruby>我慢<rt>がまん</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: I clenched my fists and held it in.

english_definition: To hit; to strike; to pound; to knock (transitive). Also used for tapping lightly depending on context.
japanese_example: <ruby>ドア<rt>どあ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>叩<rt>たた</rt></ruby>いても<ruby>返事<rt>へんじ</rt></ruby>がなかった。
english_example: Even though I knocked on the door, there was no reply.

english_definition: Toward; facing; directed at (someone/something). Often used with motion or speech: 彼に向かって言う.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>向<rt>む</rt></ruby>かってそんな<ruby>言葉<rt>ことば</rt></ruby>を<ruby>言<rt>い</rt></ruby>うな。
english_example: Don’t say words like that to him.

english_definition: To be repelled/bounced off; to be flicked away (passive/intransitive form of 弾く). Also used figuratively (e.g., rejected).
japanese_example: <ruby>ボール<rt>ぼおる</rt></ruby>が<ruby>壁<rt>かべ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>当<rt>あ</rt></ruby>たって<ruby>弾<rt>はじ</rt></ruby>かれた。
english_example: The ball hit the wall and bounced off.

english_definition: To scream/yell noisily (often in anger or panic). More chaotic/ugly than 叫ぶ in many contexts.
japanese_example: <ruby>子<rt>こ</rt></ruby>どもが<ruby>泣<rt>な</rt></ruby>きながら<ruby>喚<rt>わめ</rt></ruby>いている。
english_example: The child is screaming while crying.

english_definition: Roof (noun). Common: 屋根の上, 屋根を直す.
japanese_example: <ruby>雨<rt>あめ</rt></ruby>で<ruby>屋根<rt>やね</rt></ruby>から<ruby>水<rt>みず</rt></ruby>が<ruby>漏<rt>も</rt></ruby>れた。
english_example: Water leaked from the roof because of the rain.

english_definition: Rough/older masculine negative: “I won’t forgive/allow it.” Equivalent to 許さない with a blunt tone.
japanese_example: そんなことは<ruby>許<rt>ゆる</rt></ruby>さん。
english_example: I won’t forgive something like that.

english_definition: Not normal; not decent/sane/proper. Casual negative of まともだ; can be judgmental.
japanese_example: あの<ruby>噂<rt>うわさ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>話<rt>はなし</rt></ruby>を<ruby>聞<rt>き</rt></ruby>くほどまともじゃない。
english_example: The more I hear about that rumor, the less it sounds normal.

english_definition: To mention; to speak of; also “to put in one’s mouth” (eat/drink) depending on context. Often used as “bring up (a topic).”
japanese_example: その<ruby>名前<rt>なまえ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>二度<rt>にど</rt></ruby>と<ruby>口<rt>くち</rt></ruby>にするな。
english_example: Don’t ever mention that name again.

english_definition: I/me (old-man speech; rustic/elderly male pronoun). Used to characterize a speaker’s persona.
japanese_example: わしはまだ<ruby>負<rt>ま</rt></ruby>けん。
english_example: I’m not beaten yet.

english_definition: Deep/bright red; vividly red. Often for faces (blushing), objects, etc.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼女<rt>かのじょ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>顔<rt>かお</rt></ruby>が<ruby>真<rt>ま</rt></ruby>っ<ruby>赤<rt>か</rt></ruby>になった。
english_example: Her face turned bright red.

english_definition: Pure white; completely white. Also figuratively: 頭が真っ白 (mind goes blank).
japanese_example: <ruby>雪<rt>ゆき</rt></ruby>で<ruby>町<rt>まち</rt></ruby>が<ruby>真<rt>ま</rt></ruby>っ<ruby>白<rt>しろ</rt></ruby>だ。
english_example: The town is completely white with snow.

english_definition: Directly below; right under. Often used with の: 〜の真下.
japanese_example: <ruby>橋<rt>はし</rt></ruby>の<ruby>真下<rt>ました</rt></ruby>に<ruby>川<rt>かわ</rt></ruby>がある。
english_example: There’s a river directly under the bridge.

english_definition: Fixedly; intently; motionless (sound-symbolic adverb). Used for staring or staying still.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>はじっと<ruby>私<rt>わたし</rt></ruby>を<ruby>見<rt>み</rt></ruby>ていた。
english_example: He was staring at me intently.

english_definition: To groan/moan; to growl (low sound). Used for pain, strain, animals, or even engines metaphorically.
japanese_example: <ruby>痛<rt>いた</rt></ruby>みで<ruby>思<rt>おも</rt></ruby>わずうなった。
english_example: I groaned involuntarily from the pain.

english_definition: To help someone up (from lying/sitting). Combines 助ける + 起こす.
japanese_example: <ruby>倒<rt>たお</rt></ruby>れた<ruby>人<rt>ひと</rt></ruby>を<ruby>助<rt>たす</rt></ruby>け<ruby>起<rt>お</rt></ruby>こした。
english_example: I helped the person who had fallen to their feet.

english_definition: Groaning/straining sound (or a murmured “mm-hm”); meaning depends on context (pain vs. agreeing).
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>はうんうん<ruby>言<rt>い</rt></ruby>いながら<ruby>起<rt>お</rt></ruby>き<ruby>上<rt>あ</rt></ruby>がった。
english_example: He got up while groaning, “mm, mm.”

english_definition: Shortness of breath; being out of breath (noun). Common: 息切れがする.
japanese_example: <ruby>階段<rt>かいだん</rt></ruby>を<ruby>走<rt>はし</rt></ruby>ったら<ruby>息切<rt>いきぎ</rt></ruby>れがした。
english_example: After I ran up the stairs, I was out of breath.

english_definition: To mutter; to murmur quietly. Used for low, under-the-breath speech.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>小<rt>ちい</rt></ruby>さな<ruby>声<rt>こえ</rt></ruby>で「<ruby>疲<rt>つか</rt></ruby>れた」とつぶやいた。
english_example: He muttered in a small voice, “I’m tired.”

english_definition: Sharp; keen; piercing (senses, blade, gaze, insight). Used for both physical and mental sharpness.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼女<rt>かのじょ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>鋭<rt>するど</rt></ruby>い<ruby>観察力<rt>かんさつりょく</rt></ruby>を<ruby>持<rt>も</rt></ruby>っている。
english_example: She has keen powers of observation.

english_definition: Sideways glance; looking out of the corner of one’s eye. Often in 横目で見る.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>横目<rt>よこめ</rt></ruby>でこちらを<ruby>見<rt>み</rt></ruby>た。
english_example: He looked at me out of the corner of his eye.

english_definition: To glare at (hard, fixed stare). Stronger than 睨む; implies hostility or intimidation.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>私<rt>わたし</rt></ruby>を<ruby>睨<rt>にら</rt></ruby>みつけて<ruby>何<rt>なに</rt></ruby>も<ruby>言<rt>い</rt></ruby>わなかった。
english_example: He glared at me and said nothing.

english_definition: After (someone) came back (帰ってくる + から). Used to sequence actions after returning.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>帰<rt>かえ</rt></ruby>ってきてから、<ruby>詳<rt>くわ</rt></ruby>しく<ruby>話<rt>はな</rt></ruby>そう。
english_example: Let’s talk in detail after he comes back.

english_definition: Explosion (noun). Also used figuratively: 感情が爆発する.
japanese_example: <ruby>爆発<rt>ばくはつ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>音<rt>おと</rt></ruby>が<ruby>遠<rt>とお</rt></ruby>くで<ruby>聞<rt>き</rt></ruby>こえた。
english_example: I heard the sound of an explosion in the distance.

english_definition: Bomb (noun). Also used metaphorically (e.g., 爆弾発言: “bombshell remark”).
japanese_example: <ruby>爆弾<rt>ばくだん</rt></ruby>が<ruby>見<rt>み</rt></ruby>つかったので、<ruby>周辺<rt>しゅうへん</rt></ruby>が<ruby>封鎖<rt>ふうさ</rt></ruby>された。
english_example: A bomb was found, so the area was sealed off.

english_definition: To handle; to deal with; to treat (a topic/item/person). Used for both physical handling and subject matter coverage.
japanese_example: この<ruby>記事<rt>きじ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>環境問題<rt>かんきょうもんだい</rt></ruby>を<ruby>扱<rt>あつか</rt></ruby>っている。
english_example: This article deals with environmental issues.

english_definition: Don’t know whether ~ (question word + か + 分からない). Used for uncertainty between options or outcomes.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>来<rt>く</rt></ruby>るか<ruby>分<rt>わ</rt></ruby>からない。
english_example: I don’t know whether he’ll come.

english_definition: After all; in any case; anyway (gives a reason or emphasizes a point). Often similar to とにかく in function.
japanese_example: なにしろ<ruby>時間<rt>じかん</rt></ruby>がないから、<ruby>急<rt>いそ</rt></ruby>ごう。
english_example: Anyway, we don’t have time, so let’s hurry.

english_definition: Far from that; on the contrary (negates the previous idea and states an even stronger opposite).
japanese_example: <ruby>謝<rt>あやま</rt></ruby>るどころか、それどころか<ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>逆<rt>ぎゃく</rt></ruby>に<ruby>怒<rt>おこ</rt></ruby>り<ruby>出<rt>だ</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: Far from apologizing, he started getting angry instead.

english_definition: With all one’s might; to the fullest; completely. Used for actions done without holding back.
japanese_example: <ruby>思<rt>おも</rt></ruby>いっきり<ruby>走<rt>はし</rt></ruby>って、<ruby>汗<rt>あせ</rt></ruby>をかいた。
english_example: I ran with all my might and worked up a sweat.

english_definition: Magic (general term; often fantasy-like). Common: 魔法を使う.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼女<rt>かのじょ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>魔法<rt>まほう</rt></ruby>で<ruby>空<rt>そら</rt></ruby>を<ruby>飛<rt>と</rt></ruby>んだ。
english_example: She flew through the sky using magic.

english_definition: Sorcery; magical arts (often more technical/occult than 魔法). Used in fantasy or formalized “magic” systems.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>古<rt>ふる</rt></ruby>い<ruby>魔術<rt>まじゅつ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>研究<rt>けんきゅう</rt></ruby>している。
english_example: He is studying ancient sorcery.

english_definition: To finish; to complete (transitive). Often used for tasks/work: 仕事を終える.
japanese_example: <ruby>宿題<rt>しゅくだい</rt></ruby>を<ruby>終<rt>お</rt></ruby>えてから<ruby>遊<rt>あそ</rt></ruby>ぼう。
english_example: Let’s play after we finish our homework.

english_definition: Just finished (something) (終える + たばかり). Emphasizes that very little time has passed since completion.
japanese_example: <ruby>今<rt>いま</rt></ruby>、<ruby>仕事<rt>しょるい</rt></ruby>を<ruby>終<rt>お</rt></ruby>えたばかりです。
english_example: I’ve just finished work.

english_definition: Fresh; brand-new (often about something just made or just happened). Common: 焼きたてほやほや.
japanese_example: <ruby>焼<rt>や</rt></ruby>きたてほやほやのパンはいい<ruby>匂<rt>にお</rt></ruby>いがする。
english_example: Freshly baked bread smells wonderful.

english_definition: To be disappointed; let down. Often used when expectations are not met.
japanese_example: <ruby>試験<rt>しけん</rt></ruby>の<ruby>結果<rt>けっか</rt></ruby>を<ruby>見<rt>み</rt></ruby>てがっかりした。
english_example: I was disappointed when I saw the exam results.

english_definition: Dear; missed; longed-for (feeling of missing something/someone). Often: 〜が恋しい.
japanese_example: <ruby>故郷<rt>ふるさと</rt></ruby>の<ruby>味<rt>あじ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>恋<rt>こい</rt></ruby>しい。
english_example: I miss the flavors of my hometown.
